subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Anti-patterns
msgSnippet: I d suggest using Assert#assertEquals(String,Object,Object) to compare two different java.util.Collection implementations (e.g. ArrayList, Arrays.ArrayList) -
messageBody:
I'd suggest using Assert#assertEquals(String,Object,Object) to compare
two different java.util.Collection implementations (e.g. ArrayList,
Arrays.ArrayList) - but there's no real API-based solution to that one
unfortunately. If there's one comparison I tend to trip up on, it's that. :(
--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Andrew McDonagh wrote:
> Joe Schmetzer wrote:
>
>> I've just updated the JUnit Anti-patterns page I maintain at
>> http://www.exubero.com/junit/antipatterns.html. I'd be interested in
>> any feedback, if people want to suggest additions or improvements.
>>
>> Cheers,
>> Joe
>>
>>
>>
>
> Good start...one to add off the top of my head...
>
> Using the wrong assertXxxx
>
> Example
>
> assertTrue("errmm they dont match", obj1.equals(obj2));
>
> assertTrue("Wrong number of widgets", obj1.getWidgetsCount() != 10);
>
> Replace with AssertEquals
>
> assertEquals("errmm they dont match", obj1, obj2);
>
> assertEquals("Wrong number of widgets", 10, obj1.getWidgetsCount() );
>
>
>
>
>
>
